position.marginalia_text: Catalogus illustrium virorum in Romana Historia. Ex Aurelio Victore seriatim transcriptus. (Licèt idem ille Liber alijs attributus, pra[e]sertim Cornelio Nepoti, et Plino Ca[e]cilio.) Meorum vnus mnemonicorum Elenchorum. Proca, rex Albanoru[m]. Romulus, Romanoru[m] rex I. Numa Pompilius, Rom[anorum] rex 2. Tullus Hostilius, Rom[anorum] rex 3.

) Horatij, et Curiatij. Metius Fufetius. ( Ancus Marcius, Rom[anorum] rex 4. Tarquinius Priscus, Rom[anorum] rex V. Seruius Tullius, rex 6. Tullia. ( Tarquinius Superbus, Rom[anorum] rex 7. Tarquinius Collatinus, et Lucretia uxor. Junius Brutus, Romanoru[m] ( Consul I. Horatius Cocles. Mutius Sca[e]uola. ( Cla[e]lia virgo. Fabij trecentisex. L. Valerius Poblicola. ( Aulus Posthumius, dictator. Quinctius Cincinnatus, dictator. ( Menenius Agrippa Lanatus. Marcius Coriolanus. ( Licinius Stolo. Virginius Centurio. ( A[E]sculapius Romam aduectus; anguis specie. M. Furius Camillus. ( Manlius Capitolinus. Cornelius Cossus. Decius pater. Decius filius. ( Valerius Coruinus. Spurius Posthumius. Papyrius Cursor. Fabius Rullianus. Curius Dentatus. Appius Claudius Ca[e]cus. ( Pyrrhus, rex Epeirotarum. Fabricius. Decius Mus. ( Appius Claudius Caudex. C. Duilius. Atilius Calatinus. ( Atilius Regulus. Lutatius Catulus. Annibal, Carthaginiensis dux. Q. Fabius Maximus. Cunctator. P. Scipio Nasica. M. Claudius Marcellus. Liuia Claudia, uirgo vestalis. Porcius Cato Censorius. Claudius Nero; et Asdrubal frater Annibalis. P. Cornelius Scipio Africanus. M. Liuius Salinator. Quinctius Flaminius. aliàs Flamininus. Fuluius Nobilior. L. Scipio Asiaticus. ( Antiochus, rex Syria[e]. Cn. Manlius Vulso. Paulus A[E]mylius Macedonicus. ( Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus. P. Scipio A[E]milianus. ( C. Hostilius Mancinus. L. Mummius Achaicus. ( Q. Ca[e]cilius Metellus Macedonicus. Q. Ca[e]cilius Metellus Numidicus. Q. Metellus Pius. ( Tiberius Gracchus. Caius Gracchus. M. Liuius Drusus. Marius pater. Marius filius. ( Cornelius Cinna. Flauius Fimbria. Viriatus Lusitanus.

) M. Æmylius Scaurus. L. Appuleius Saturninus. L. Licinius Lucullus. L. Cornelius Sulla. Mithradates, rex Ponti. Cn. Pompeius Magnus. Atq[ue] hi illustrium Romanoru[m] pra[e]stantissimi. Nisi quòd in antiquo Additamento, hi etiam celebrantur illustres viri. Julius Ca[e]sar. Octauianus Ca[e]sar. Cato Pra[e]torius. M. Tullius Cicero. Marcus Brutus. C. Cassius Longinus. Sextus Pompeius. Marcus Antonius. Cleopatra regina. In excellentissima Romana[e] Reip[ublicae] historia, Eccè illustrium iam tum virorum selectissimi: pra[e]sertim suorum omnium fortissimi, atq[ue] prudentissimi. Nec vllus ferè mnemonicus Elenchus, altiori dignus impressione. Tanti ubiq[ue] momenti, ista pra[e]clara nomina. In quibus, qua[e]dam totius Romana[e] historia[e] ars memoratiua conspicùe repra[e]sentatur.

marginalia.translation: A catalogue of famous men in Roman history, copied in sequence from Aurelius Victor. (Although the same book has been attributed to others, in particular Cornelius Nepos and Pliny the Younger.) This is one of my lists for memory. Procas, king of the people of Alba Longa. Romulus, the first king of the Romans. Numa Pompilius, the second king of the Romans. Tullus Hostilius, the third king of the Romans. The Horatii, and Curiatii. Mettius Fufetius. Ancus Marcius, the fourth king of the Romans. Tarquinius Priscus, the fifth king of the Romans. Servius Tullius, the sixth king of the Romans. Tullia. Tarquinius Superbus, the seventh king of the Romans. Tarquinius Collatinus and his wife Lucretia. Junius Brutus, the first consul of the Romans. Horatius Cocles. Mucius Scaevola. The virgin Claelia. The 306 Fabii. Lucius Valerius Poplicola. The dictator Aulus Postumius. The dictator Quinctius Cincinnatus. Menenius Agrippa Lanatus. Marcius Coriolanus. Licinius Stolo. Virginius Centurio. Aesculapius brought to Rome, in the guise of a snake. Marcus Furius Camillus. Manlius Capitolinus. Cornelius Cossus. The elder Decius. The younger Decius. Valerius Corvinus. Spurius Postumius. Papirius Cursor. Fabius Rullianus. Curius Dentatus. Appius Claudius Caecus. Pyrrhus, king of the people of Epirus. Fabricius. Decius Mus. Appius Claudius Caudex. Gaius Duilius. Atilius Calatinus. Atilius Regulus. Lutatius Catulus. Hannibal, the Carthagian general. Quintus Fabius Maximus Cunctator. Publius Scipio Nasica. Marcus Claudius Marcellus. Livia Claudia, the vestal virgin. Cato the Elder. Nero and Hasdrubal, Hannibal’s brother. Scipio Africanus. Marcus Livius Salinator. Quinctius Flaminius, also called Flamininus. Fulvius Nobilior. Lucius Scipio Asiaticus. Antiochus, king of Syria. Gnaeus Manlius Vulso. Aemilius Paullus Macedonicus. Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus. Publius Scipio Aemilianus. Gaius Hostilius Mancinus. Lucius Mummius Achaicus. Quintus Caecilius Metellus Macedonicus. Quintus Caecilius Metellus Numidicus. Quintus Metellus Pius. Tiberius Gracchus. Gaius Gracchus. Marcus Livius Drusus. Marius the elder. Marius the younger. Cornelius Cinna. Flavius Fimbria. Viriatus Lusitanus. Marcus Aemilius Scaurus. Lucius Appuleius Saturnius. Lucius Licinius Lucullus. Sulla. Mithridates, king of Pontus. Pompey. These are the most outstanding of the famous Romans, except that in an ancient supplement the following famous men are also praised: Julius Caesar; Augustus Caesar; Cato the Younger; Cicero; Brutus; Gaius Cassius Longinus; Sextus Pompey; Mark Antony; Queen Cleopatra. These, then, are the most select of already famous men, from the superior history of the Roman Republic, in particular the bravest and wisest of them all. Hardly any other memory list deserves a deeper imprint, so great is the importance of those brilliant names. In them is strikingly represented the art of remembering all Roman history.
A golden list of the most famous Romans.
